Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Company: TRANSCONTINENTAL GAS PIPE LINE CO LLC
Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on February 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data was a spreadsheet version of information contained in individual case documents that can be retrieved at https://www.ahs.dep.pa.gov/eFACTSWeb/default.aspx

Description: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) personnel conducted an inspection of the Mid-Continent Fractionation and Storage facility in Conway, Kan., in April 2012. As a result of the inspection, Mid-Continent has agreed to spend approximately $2 million to construct and operate a system to reduce emissions of volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors to the atmosphere.

Description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation (Transco) under which the company agreed to test for and clean up soil and groundwater contamination related to waste disposal at numerous compressor stations along its natural gas pipeline. In addition, the company agreed to clean up polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) contamination, complete a storm water monitoring program, conduct storm water sampling at several compressor stations and pay a $1.4 million civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency today announced agreements with two gas production companies resolving alleged violations of the Clean Air Act on the Southern Ute Reservation in Colorado's San Juan Basin. The agreements, outlined in separate consent decrees with Williams and ConocoPhillips, will reduce emissions of air pollutants from a gas plant and compressor stations.

Private Litigation Case Title: Nelson, et al v. Williams Co Inc., et al

Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Description: Williams agreed to pay $15 million to resolve allegations of market manipulation and antitrust violations during the 2000-2001 West Coast energy crisis.

Williams Energy Marketing & Trading agreed to a $417 million settlement of allegations that it illegally priced its energy and unjustly profited by double-selling its electricity. California was the primary plaintiff but the attorneys general of Washington and Oregon also participated in the case and received shares of the settlement.
Williams Pipe Line Co. agreed to pay $300,000 in settlement of allegations of air pollution  violations from gasoline fumes during loading of tanker trucks.

Williams Pipe Line Co. agreed to pay a civil penalty, a payment for environmental education, and a payment for the state to purchase property for a wildlife habitat, in settlement of allegations of violations stemming from petroleum spills in Menard and Logan counties.

Info Source: List of FY2002 ADEM Administrative Orders obtained via an open records request on October 5, 2020.
